{
  "article_text": [
    "in @xcite , riley introduced an infinite collection of laurent polynomials , called the heckoid polynomials , associated with a @xmath0-bridge link @xmath1 , and observed , through extensive computer experiments , that these heckoid polynomials define the affine representation variety of certain groups , the heckoid groups for @xmath1 . to be more precise ,",
    "he `` defines '' the heckoid group of index @xmath2 for @xmath1 to be a kleinian group generated by two parabolic transformations which are obtained by choosing a `` right '' root of the heckoid polynomials ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* the paragraph following theorem  a in p.390 ) ) .",
    "the classical hecke groups , introduced in @xcite , are essentially the simplest heckoid groups .",
    "riley discussed relations of the heckoid polynomials with the polynomials defining the nonabelian @xmath3-representations of @xmath0-bridge link groups introduced in @xcite , and proved that each heckoid polynomial divides the nonabelian representation polynomials of @xmath0-bridge links @xmath4 , where @xmath4 belongs to an infinite collection of @xmath0-bridge links determined by @xmath1 and the index @xmath5 .",
    "this suggests that there are epimorphisms from the link group of @xmath4 onto the heckoid group of index @xmath5 for @xmath1 , as observed in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* the paragraph following theorem  b in p.391 ) .",
    "the purpose of this paper is ( i ) to give an explicit combinatorial definition of the heckoid groups for @xmath0-bridge links ( definition  [ def : odd_heckoid_group ] ) , ( ii ) to prove that the heckoid groups are identified with kleinian groups generated by two parabolic transformations ( theorem  [ thm.kleinian_heckoid ] ) , and ( iii ) to give a systematic construction of epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto heckoid groups , generalizing riley s construction ( theorem  [ thm : epimorophism ] and remark  [ rem : rileys_theorem ] ) .",
    "we note that the results ( i ) and ( ii ) are essentially contained in the work of agol  @xcite , in which he announces a complete classification of the non - free kleinian groups generated by two - parabolic transformations .",
    "moreover , this classification theorem gives a nice characterization of the heckoid groups , by showing that they are exactly the kleinian groups , with nontrivial torsion , generated by two - parabolic transformations .",
    "the result ( iii ) is an analogy of the systematic construction of epimorphisms between @xmath0-bridge link groups given in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  1.1 ) . in the sequel",
    "@xcite of this paper , we prove , by using small cancellation theory , that the epimorphisms in theorem  [ thm : epimorophism ] are the only upper - meridian - pair - preserving epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto _ even _ heckoid groups . this in turn forms an analogy of ( * ?",
    "* main theorem  2.4 ) , which gives a complete characterization of upper - meridian - pair - preserving epimorphisms between @xmath0-bridge link groups .",
    "this paper is organized as follows . in section  [ statements ] , we describe the main results . in section  [ fricke_surfaces ] , we give an explicit combinatorial definition of heckoid groups .",
    "sections  [ sec : proof_if_part ] , [ sec : topological - description ] and [ sec : kleinian - heckod - groups ] , respectively , are devoted to the proof of theorem  [ thm : epimorophism ] , the topological description of heckoid orbifolds , and the proof of theorem  [ thm.kleinian_heckoid ] .    throughout this paper",
    ", we denote the orbifold fundamental group of an orbifold @xmath6 by @xmath7 .",
    "consider the discrete group , @xmath8 , of isometries of the euclidean plane @xmath9 generated by the @xmath10-rotations around the points in the lattice @xmath11 . set @xmath12 and call it the _ conway sphere_. then @xmath13 is homeomorphic to the 2-sphere , and @xmath14 consists of four points in @xmath13 .",
    "we also call @xmath13 the conway sphere .",
    "let @xmath15 be the complementary 4-times punctured sphere . for each @xmath16 ,",
    "let @xmath17 be the simple loop in @xmath18 obtained as the projection of a line in @xmath19 of slope @xmath20 .",
    "then @xmath17 is _ essential _ in @xmath18 , i.e. , it does not bound a disk in @xmath18 and is not homotopic to a loop around a puncture .",
    "conversely , any essential simple loop in @xmath18 is isotopic to @xmath17 for a unique @xmath21 .",
    "then @xmath20 is called the _ slope _ of the simple loop .",
    "we abuse notation to denote by @xmath17 the pair of conjugacy classes in @xmath22 represented by the loop @xmath17 with two possible orientations .",
    "a _ trivial tangle _ is a pair @xmath23 , where @xmath24 is a 3-ball and @xmath25 is a union of two arcs properly embedded in @xmath24 which is simultaneously parallel to a union of two mutually disjoint arcs in @xmath26 . let @xmath27 be the simple unknotted arc in @xmath24 joining the two components of @xmath25 as illustrated in figure  [ fig.trivial-tangle ] .",
    "we call it the _ core tunnel _ of the trivial tangle .",
    "pick a base point @xmath28 in @xmath29 , and let @xmath30 be the generating pair of the fundamental group @xmath31 each of which is represented by a based loop consisting of a small peripheral simple loop around a component of @xmath25 and a subarc of @xmath27 joining the circle to @xmath28 . for any base point @xmath32",
    ", the generating pair of @xmath33 corresponding to the generating pair @xmath30 of @xmath31 via a path joining @xmath34 to @xmath28 is denoted by the same symbol .",
    "the pair @xmath30 is unique up to ( i ) reversal of the order , ( ii ) replacement of one of the members with its inverse , and ( iii ) simultaneous conjugation .",
    "we call the equivalence class of @xmath30 the _ meridian pair _ of @xmath35 .     a trivial tangle ]    by a _ rational tangle _ , we mean a trivial tangle @xmath23 which is endowed with a homeomorphism from @xmath36 to @xmath37 . through the homeomorphism",
    "we identify the boundary of a rational tangle with the conway sphere .",
    "thus the slope of an essential simple loop in @xmath38 is defined .",
    "we define the _ slope _ of a rational tangle to be the slope of an essential loop on @xmath39 which bounds a disk in @xmath24 separating the components of @xmath25 .",
    "( such a loop is unique up to isotopy on @xmath39 and is called a _ meridian _ of the rational tangle . )",
    "we denote a rational tangle of slope @xmath40 by @xmath41 .",
    "by van kampen s theorem , the fundamental group @xmath42 is identified with the quotient @xmath43 , where @xmath44 denotes the normal closure .    for each @xmath45 ,",
    "the _ 2-bridge link @xmath46 of slope @xmath40 _ is defined to be the sum of the rational tangles of slopes @xmath47 and @xmath40 , namely , @xmath48 is obtained from @xmath49 and @xmath41 by identifying their boundaries through the identity map on the conway sphere @xmath37 .",
    "( recall that the boundaries of rational tangles are identified with the conway sphere . )",
    "@xmath46 has one or two components according as the denominator of @xmath40 is odd or even .",
    "we call @xmath49 and @xmath41 , respectively , the _ upper tangle _ and _ lower tangle _ of the 2-bridge link . by van kampen s theorem , the link group @xmath50 is obtained as follows : @xmath51 we call the image in the link group of the meridian pair of @xmath52 ( resp .",

    "@xmath55 is the @xmath0-bridge link with @xmath56 $ ] ( with a single component ) .",
    "the rational tangles @xmath57 and @xmath58 , respectively , are the outside and the inside of the bridge sphere @xmath13 . ]    for a rational number @xmath40 ( @xmath59 ) and an integer @xmath60 , the ( _ even _ ) _ heckoid orbifold , @xmath53 , of index @xmath54 for the @xmath0-bridge link @xmath46 _ is the @xmath61-orbifold as shown in figure  [ fig.hekoid-orbifold ] .",

    "kampen s theorem for orbifold fundamental groups ( cf .",
    "* corollary  2.3 ) ) , we have @xmath66 in particular , the even heckoid group @xmath64 is a two - generator and one - relator group .",
    "we call the image in @xmath64 of the meridian pair of @xmath52 the _ upper meridian pair_.    the announcement by agol  @xcite and the announcement made in the second author s joint work with akiyoshi , wada and yamashita  ( * ? ?",
    "? * section  3 of preface ) ( cf .",
    "remark  [ rem : aswy ] ) suggest that the group @xmath64 makes sense even when @xmath54 is a half - integer greater than @xmath67 .",
    "the precise definition of @xmath64 with @xmath68 a half - integer is given in definition  [ def : odd_heckoid_group ] , and a topological description of the corresponding orbifold , @xmath53 , is given by proposition  [ prop : odd - heckoid - orbifold ] ( see figures  [ odd - heckoid - orbifold1 ] and  [ odd - heckoid - orbifold2 ] ) .",
    "when @xmath68 is a non - integral half - integer , @xmath64 and @xmath53 , respectively , are called the ( _ odd _ ) _ heckoid orbifold _ and the ( _ odd _ ) _ heckoid group _ of index @xmath54 for @xmath46 .",
    "there is a natural epimorphism from @xmath52 onto the odd heckoid group @xmath64 , and the image of the meridian pair of @xmath52 is called the _ upper meridian pair _ of @xmath64 .",
    "thus the odd heckoid groups are also two - generator groups .",
    "however , we show that they are not one - relator groups ( proposition  [ prop - not - one - relator ] ) .",
    "our terminology is slightly different from that of @xcite , where @xmath64 is called the heckoid group of index `` @xmath69 '' for @xmath46 .",
    "the heckoid orbifold @xmath53 and the heckoid group @xmath64 are _ even _ or _ odd _ according to whether riley s index @xmath69 is even or odd .",
    "we prove the following theorem , which was anticipated in @xcite and is contained in @xcite without proof .",
    "[ thm.kleinian_heckoid ] for @xmath40 a rational number and @xmath68 an integer or a half - integer , the heckoid group @xmath64 is isomorphic to a geometrically finite kleinian group generated by two parabolic transformations .    in order to explain a systematic construction of epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto heckoid groups , we prepare a few notation .",
    "let @xmath70 be the _",
    "farey tessellation _ ,",
    "that is , the tessellation of the upper half space @xmath71 by ideal triangles which are obtained from the ideal triangle with the ideal vertices @xmath72 by repeated reflection in the edges .",
    "then @xmath73 is identified with the set of the ideal vertices of @xmath70 . for each @xmath45 , let @xmath74 be the group of automorphisms of @xmath70 generated by reflections in the edges of @xmath70 with an endpoint @xmath40 .",

    "then we have the following systematic construction of epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto heckoid groups .",
    "[ thm : epimorophism ] suppose that @xmath40 is a rational number and that @xmath68 is an integer or a half - integer .",
    "for @xmath21 , if @xmath20 or @xmath78 belongs to the @xmath76-orbit of @xmath47 , then there is an upper - meridian - pair - preserving epimorphism from @xmath79 to @xmath64 .",
    "this theorem may be regarded as a generalization of theorem  b and theorem  3 of riley  @xcite .",
    "in fact , they correspond to the case when @xmath20 belongs to the orbit of @xmath47 by the infinite cyclic subgroup @xmath75 of @xmath76 ( see remark  [ rem : rileys_theorem ] ) .    the above theorem is actually obtained from the following theorem .",
    "[ thm : fundametal_domain ] suppose that @xmath40 is a rational number and that @xmath68 is an integer or a half - integer .",
    "let @xmath20 and @xmath80 be elements of @xmath73 which belong to the same @xmath76-orbit . then the conjugacy classes @xmath17 and @xmath81 in @xmath64 are equal . in particular , if @xmath20 belongs to the @xmath76-orbit of @xmath47 , then @xmath17 is the trivial conjugacy class in @xmath64 .",

    "this result corresponds to the case when @xmath243 and @xmath244 $ ] , where @xmath245 with @xmath246 in proposition  [ prop : continued fraction ] .",
    "in fact , a simple calculation shows @xmath247 where @xmath248 is the length of @xmath222 and @xmath249 is chosen so that @xmath250 . thus theorem  [ thm : epimorophism ] and proposition  [ prop : continued fraction ]",
    "imply that there is an epimorphism from the link group @xmath251 onto the heckoid group @xmath252 , recovering riley s result .",
    "in this section , we show , following the sketch of agol  @xcite , that the orbifold @xmath127 and the odd heckoid orbifold @xmath53 are depicted as in figures  [ odd - heckoid - orbifold1 ] and [ odd - heckoid - orbifold2 ] . here , we employ the following convention .     the case when @xmath46 is a knot and @xmath253 is an odd integer . here",

    "[ conv : orbifold ]    let @xmath256 be a trivalent graph properly embedded in a compact @xmath61-manifold @xmath257 such that each edge @xmath258 of @xmath256 is given a _ weight _ @xmath259 . here",
    ", a loop component of @xmath256 is regarded as an edge .",

    "in this section , we prove theorem  [ thm.kleinian_heckoid ] , which is contained in the announcement by agol  @xcite .",
    "as noted in @xcite , the proof relies on the orbifold theorem and is analogous to the arguments in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proof of theorem  9 ) .",
    "[ rem : aswy ] this theorem also follows from the announcement made in the second author s joint work with akiyoshi , wada and yamashita  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* section  3 of preface ) .",
    "note , however , that there is an error in the assertion 5 in page ix in preface , though a special case is treated correctly in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  5.3.9 ) .",
    "in fact , the first sentence of the assertion should be read as follows : the holonomy group of @xmath358 is discrete if and only if @xmath359 . the second author would also like to note that this assertion can be proved by using the argument of parkkonen in ( * ? ? ? * lemma  7.5 ) ; this was forgotten to mention in @xcite , though the paper is included in the bibliography .    in order to prove theorem  [ thm.kleinian_heckoid ]",
    ", we prove that @xmath127 with @xmath360 admits a hyperbolic structure . throughout this section",
    ", we identify @xmath127 with the orbifold @xmath269 in proposition  [ prop : quotient - heckoid - orbifold ] .",
    "we denote by @xmath361 and @xmath362 the @xmath61-balls of @xmath363 bounded by the bridge sphere of @xmath46 such that @xmath364 we refer to ( * ? ? ? * introduction and section  8) ( cf .",
    "* chapter  2 ) , ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter  2 ) and ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter  6 ) ) for standard terminologies for orbifolds .",
    "[ lem : irreducible ] for a rational number @xmath40 and an integer @xmath236 , the following hold .    1",
    ".   @xmath127 does not contain a bad @xmath0-suborbifold .",
    "any football @xmath365 in @xmath127 bounds a discal @xmath61-suborbifold .",
    "3 .   @xmath127 does not contain an essential turnover .",
    "@xmath127 is topologically atoroidal , i.e. , it does not contain an essential orientable toric @xmath0-suborbifold .",
    "\\(1 ) suppose that @xmath127 contains a bad @xmath0-suborbifold , @xmath154",
    ". then @xmath154 is either a _ teardrop _ @xmath366 or a _ spindle _ @xmath367 with @xmath368 . since the indices of the singular set of @xmath127 are @xmath0 and @xmath369 , and since the underlying @xmath0-sphere @xmath159 intersects @xmath46 in an even number of points , we see that @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath46 and intersects ( at least ) one of the unknotting tunnels @xmath370 transversely in a single point , where @xmath371 , @xmath372 or @xmath373 . since the endpoints of each of the unknotting tunnels are contained in @xmath46",
    ", this implies that @xmath46 is a split link , a contradiction .",
    "hence @xmath127 can not contain a bad @xmath0-suborbifold .",
    "\\(2 ) let @xmath154 be a suborbifold of @xmath127 which is a football .",
    "as in ( 1 ) , we see that one of the following holds .    1",
    ".   @xmath159 intersects @xmath46 in two points , where @xmath374 .",
    "2 .   @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath46 and intersects one of the unknotting tunnels @xmath370 in two points and does not intersect the other unknotting tunnel , where @xmath374 or @xmath375 .",
    "suppose that condition ( i ) holds .",
    "then @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath376 , and so either @xmath270 and @xmath271 are separated by @xmath159 , or @xmath376 is contained in a single component of @xmath377 . if @xmath270 and @xmath271 are separated by @xmath159 , then @xmath159 must intersect @xmath46 in at least four points , a contradiction . hence @xmath376 is contained in a single component of @xmath377 .",
    "let @xmath378 and @xmath379 be the @xmath61-balls in @xmath363 bounded by @xmath159 , such that @xmath380 .",
    "set @xmath381 ( @xmath382 ) .",
    "then the genus @xmath61 open handle body @xmath383 is the union of @xmath384 and @xmath385 along the open annuls @xmath386 , and hence the rank @xmath61 free group , @xmath387 , is the free product of @xmath388 and @xmath389 with the infinite cyclic amalgamated subgroup @xmath390 .",
    "since @xmath391 , this implies @xmath392 . hence @xmath393 is a trivial @xmath67-string tangle .",
    "thus @xmath394 determines a discal @xmath61-suborbifold of @xmath127 bounded by @xmath154 , and therefore @xmath154 is inessential .",
    "suppose that condition ( ii ) holds . for simplicity , we assume that @xmath159 intersects @xmath270 in two points and does not intersect @xmath271 .",
    "( the other case is treated similarly . )",
    "let @xmath395 be the @xmath61-ball bounded by @xmath159 such that @xmath396 is a subarc of @xmath270 .",
    "then @xmath397 is a trivial @xmath67-string tangle , because @xmath270 is contained in a trivial constituent knot in the spatial graph @xmath398 .",
    "hence it determines a discal @xmath61-suborbifold of @xmath127 bounded by @xmath154 .",
    "\\(3 ) suppose that @xmath127 contains an essential turnover @xmath399 .",
    "then either @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath46 , or @xmath159 intersects @xmath46 in two points . in the first case , @xmath159 intersects @xmath400 in three points and hence @xmath159 intersects @xmath270 or @xmath271 in an odd number of points .",
    "as in ( 1 ) , it follows that @xmath46 is a split link , a contradiction .",
    "hence we may assume that @xmath159 intersects @xmath46 in two points , and therefore @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath270 or @xmath271 .",
    "for simplicity , we assume that @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath271 . ( the other case is treated similarly . ) by using the fact that @xmath159 is also disjoint from @xmath401 and the fact that @xmath402 is a relative regular neighborhood of @xmath271 in @xmath403 , we can see that @xmath154 is isotopic to a @xmath0-suborbifold which is disjoint from the suborbifold @xmath404 .",
    "hence we may assume that @xmath154 is contained in the interior of the suborbifold @xmath405 .",
    "let @xmath406 ( @xmath407 ) be the edges of @xmath408 as illustrated in the right figures in figure  [ covering - rational - tangle ] .",
    "note that @xmath409 , @xmath410 and @xmath411 ( @xmath412 ) .",
    "thus @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath413 and @xmath159 intersects @xmath414 transversely in three points .",
    "let @xmath415 be the disk properly embedded in @xmath361 determined by the plane in which figure  [ covering - rational - tangle ] is drawn .",
    "then @xmath415 contains the graph @xmath416 .",
    "we may assume that @xmath159 is transversal to @xmath415 and hence @xmath417 consists of mutually disjoint circles . by using the irreducibility of @xmath418 ,",
    "we may assume , by a standard argument , that no component of @xmath417 bounds a disk disjoint from @xmath416 .",
    "then it follows that @xmath417 must consist of a single circle which intersects @xmath270 , @xmath419 and @xmath420 in a single point .",
    "let @xmath421 be the disk in @xmath415 bounded by the circle @xmath422 , and let @xmath423 be the @xmath61-ball in @xmath424 bounded by @xmath159 . then @xmath421 is properly embedded in @xmath423 , and @xmath425 .",
    "hence @xmath426 determines a discal @xmath61-orbifold bounded by the turnover @xmath154 , a contradiction .",
    "\\(4 ) suppose that @xmath127 contains an essential pillow @xmath427 .",
    "then @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath271 , which has index @xmath236 , and hence we may assume , as in ( 3 ) , that @xmath159 is contained in the suborbifold @xmath405 . under the notation in ( 3 ) , @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath413 and @xmath159 intersects @xmath416 transversely in four points .",
    "we may also assume that @xmath159 is transversal to the disk @xmath415 introduced in ( 3 ) and hence @xmath417 consists of mutually disjoint circles . by using the irreducibility of @xmath418 and the assumption that @xmath154 is essential",
    ", we may assume that no component of @xmath417 bounds a disk disjoint from @xmath416 .",
    "hence we see that either ( i ) @xmath417 consists of a single loop which intersects @xmath428 in four points , or ( ii ) @xmath417 consists of two loops each of which intersects @xmath428 in two points . in either case , we can find an `` outermost disk '' @xmath429 in @xmath415 satisfying the following conditions .    1 .",
    "@xmath430 is an arc , @xmath431 , in @xmath432 .",
    "@xmath433 is an arc , @xmath434 , in @xmath432 which is contained in the interior of an edge of the graph @xmath408 .",
    "3 .   @xmath435 .",
    "@xmath429 is contained in the @xmath61-ball , @xmath423 , in @xmath361 which is bounded by @xmath159 .",
    "then the frontier of a regular neighborhood of @xmath429 in @xmath423 is a disk properly embedded in @xmath423 disjoint from the singular set , whose boundary is an essential loop in the pillow @xmath154 .",
    "this contradicts the assumption that @xmath154 is essential .",
    "hence @xmath127 does not contain an essential pillow .",
    "assume that @xmath127 contains an essential torus , @xmath154 .",
    "then @xmath154 is a torus contained in @xmath436 , which is a genus @xmath61 open handlebody .",
    "hence @xmath154 must be compressible in @xmath436 , a contradiction .    by the classification of toric @xmath0-orbifolds ,",
    "an orientable toric @xmath0-orbifold is a torus , a turnover or a pillow .",
    "hence by ( 3 ) and the above arguments , @xmath127 does not contain an essential orientable toric @xmath0-orbifold .",
    "[ lem : haken ] for a rational number @xmath40 and an integer @xmath236 , the orbifold @xmath127 is haken , i.e. , it is irreducible and does not contain an essential turnover , but contains an essential @xmath0-suborbifold .    by lemma  [ lem : irreducible](1 ) , @xmath127 does not contain a bad @xmath0-suborbifold . by lemma  [ lem : irreducible](2 ) and ( 3 ) , every orientable spherical @xmath0-suborbifold of @xmath127 with nonempty singular set bounds a discal @xmath61-suborbifold . moreover any @xmath0-sphere ( i.e. , spherical @xmath0-suborbifold with empty singular set ) of @xmath127 bounds a @xmath61-ball in @xmath127 , because proposition  [ prop : quotient - heckoid - orbifold ] implies that the complement of an open regular neighborhood of the singular set of @xmath127 is homeomorphic to a genus @xmath61 handlebody .",
    "hence the orbifold @xmath127 is irreducible .",
    "moreover , it does not contain an essential turnover by lemma  [ lem : irreducible](3 ) . since @xmath437 is not a turnover , we see by (",
    "* proposition  4.6 ) that @xmath127 is haken ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition  8.0.1 ) ) .",
    "[ lem : hyperbolic ] for a rational number @xmath40 and an integer @xmath236 , the orbifold @xmath127 is homotopically atoroidal , i.e. , @xmath150 is not virtually abelian and every rank @xmath0 free abelian subgroup of @xmath150 is peripheral .",
    "since @xmath127 is haken by lemma  [ lem : haken ] , we see by ( * ? ? ? * theorem  a ) ( cf .",
    "* proposition  8.2.2 ) ) that @xmath127 is good , i.e. , it has a manifold cover .",
    "suppose on the contrary that @xmath127 is not homotopically atoroidal ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* definition  8.2.13 ) ) .",
    "then , since @xmath127 is topologically atoroidal by lemma  [ lem : irreducible](4 ) , we see by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  8.2.11 ) that @xmath127 is either euclidean or seifert fibered .",
    "( here , we use the fact that @xmath127 is good . )",
    "this contradicts the fact that @xmath437 is not euclidian .",
    "hence the orbifold @xmath127 is homotopically atoroidal .",
    "[ cor : hyperbolic ] for a rational number @xmath40 and an integer @xmath236 , the interior of @xmath127 has a geometrically finite hyperbolic structure . in particular , @xmath127 is very good , i.e. , it has a finite cover which is a manifold .    by lemmas [ lem : haken ] and [ lem : hyperbolic ]",
    ", @xmath127 is a homotopically atoroidal haken @xmath61-orbifold .",
    "hence , by the orbifold theorem for haken orbifolds ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  8.2.14 ) , @xmath127 is hyperbolic .",
    "moreover , it follows from the proof of the theorem that the hyperbolic structure can be chosen to be geometrically finite .",
    "the last assertion follows from selberg s lemma @xcite ( cf .",
    "* theorem  2.29 ) ) .",
    "let @xmath438 .",
    "then @xmath439 is an annular @xmath0-suborbifold in @xmath401 , and the following lemma shows that @xmath440 is a pared @xmath61-orbifold ( see ( * ? ?",
    "* definition  8.3.7 ) ) .",
    "[ lem : pared_orbifold ] for a rational number @xmath40 and an integer @xmath236 , the pair @xmath440 satisfies the following conditions , and hence it is a pared @xmath61-orbifold .    1 .",
    "@xmath127 is irreducible and very good .",
    "@xmath441 is incompressible .",
    "every rank @xmath0 free abelian subgroup of @xmath150 is conjugate to a subgroup of @xmath442 .",
    "( in fact , @xmath150 does not contain a rank @xmath0 free abelian subgroup . )",
    "any properly embedded annular @xmath0-suborbifold @xmath443 whose boundary rests on essential loops in @xmath441 is parallel to @xmath441 .",
    "\\(1 ) this follows from lemma  [ lem : haken ] and corollary  [ cor : hyperbolic ] .",
    "\\(2 ) suppose that @xmath441 is compressible .",
    "then there is a discal orbifold @xmath444 properly embedded in @xmath440 such that @xmath445 is a loop in @xmath441 parallel to @xmath446 .",
    "since @xmath154 has at most one cone point , @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath270 or @xmath271 . for simplicity , we assume that @xmath159 is disjoint from @xmath271 .",
    "( the other case is treated similarly . ) by using the fact that @xmath445 is parallel to @xmath446 in @xmath447 , and the fact that @xmath402 is a relative regular neighborhood of @xmath271 in @xmath403 , we can see that @xmath154 is isotopic to a @xmath0-suborbifold which is disjoint from the suborbifold @xmath404 .",
    "hence we may assume that @xmath154 is contained in the interior of the suborbifold @xmath405 .",
    "then , by looking at the intersection of @xmath159 with the disk @xmath415 as in the proof of lemma  [ lem : irreducible](3 ) , we see that this can not happen .",
    "\\(3 ) suppose that @xmath150 contains a rank @xmath0 free abelian subgroup , @xmath8 .",
    "then @xmath8 is conjugate to a subgroup of @xmath448 by lemma  [ lem : hyperbolic ] , where @xmath449 is the inclusion . if @xmath450 is injective , then @xmath451 is isomorphic to a fuchsian group and hence it can not contain a rank @xmath0 free abelian subgroup , a contradiction .",
    "so , @xmath450 is not injective . by the loop theorem for good orbifolds",
    "@xcite , @xmath401 is compressible .",
    "let @xmath452 be a compressing disk for @xmath401 .",
    "then @xmath453 , @xmath0 or @xmath157 , and @xmath445 is a loop in @xmath401 separating the @xmath454 singular points into two pairs of singular points .",
    "thus the result of compression of @xmath401 by @xmath154 is a union of two @xmath0-suborbifolds , @xmath455 and @xmath456 . if @xmath453 , @xmath457 is a bad @xmath0-suborbifold , a contradiction to lemma  [ lem : irreducible](1 ) .",
    "hence @xmath458 or @xmath157 , and therefore @xmath459 and @xmath460 are turnovers . by lemma  [ lem : irreducible](3 ) , they must be inessential . since none of them is boundary parallel ,",
    "each @xmath461 is a spherical turnover bounding a discal @xmath61-orbifold .",
    "note that the singular set of @xmath127 has exactly two vertices and the boundaries of regular neighborhoods of the vertices are @xmath462 and @xmath463 ( see proposition  [ prop : quotient - heckoid - orbifold ] ) .",
    "hence we see @xmath458 and @xmath459 and @xmath460 are the boundaries of regular neighborhoods of the two vertices .",
    "thus @xmath401 is parallel to the boundary of the @xmath61-orbifold obtained from the regular neighborhoods of the two vertices of the singular set by joining them by a tube around the unique edge of the singular set ( of index @xmath0 ) joining the two vertices .",
    "thus @xmath150 is a free product of the dihedral groups of orders @xmath454 and @xmath114 with amalgamated subgroup isomorphic to @xmath254 .",
    "it is easy to see that such a group can not contain a rank @xmath0 free abelian subgroup .",
    "hence , @xmath150 does not contain a rank @xmath0 free abelian subgroup .",
    "\\(4 ) let @xmath464 be an annular @xmath0-suborbifold properly embedded in @xmath440 whose boundary rests on essential loops in @xmath441 .",
    "suppose first that @xmath465 is an annulus .",
    "then @xmath465 is disjoint from @xmath400 .",
    "since each component of @xmath466 is parallel to @xmath446 in @xmath467 , we may assume as in ( 2 ) that @xmath465 is embedded in a regular neighborhood of the @xmath0-suborbifold of @xmath468 determined by the @xmath0-bridge sphere .",
    "thus @xmath464 is regarded as a suborbifold of @xmath469 , p')$ ] , where @xmath140 is obtained from the conway sphere @xmath18 by removing an open regular neighborhood of a puncture and filling in order @xmath0 cone points to the remaining punctures ( cf .",
    "proof of proposition  [ prop : quotient - heckoid - orbifold ] ) , and @xmath470 is the product annulus @xmath471 $ ] . consider a disk properly embedded in @xmath472 $ ] which contains the singular set . by looking at the intersection of @xmath465 with the disk",
    ", we can find a boundary compressing disk for @xmath465 . by the irreducibility of the complement of the singular set of @xmath134 $ ] , this implies that @xmath465 is parallel to an annulus in @xmath473 .",
    "suppose next that @xmath465 is homeomorphic to @xmath474 .",
    "then @xmath465 is disjoint from @xmath271 , which has index @xmath236 .",
    "since @xmath466 is parallel to @xmath446 in @xmath467 , we see as in the above that @xmath465 is contained in the suborbifold @xmath405 . by looking at the intersection of @xmath475 with the disk @xmath415 as in the proof of lemma  [ lem : irreducible](3 ) , we can see that @xmath465 is parallel to the suborbifold of @xmath441 bounded by @xmath466 .",
    "since @xmath150 is not virtually abelian by lemma  [ lem : hyperbolic ] , we obtain the following proposition by lemma  [ lem : pared_orbifold ] and by the orbifold theorem for haken pared orbifolds ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  8.3.9 ) .",
    "[ prop : hyperbolic - pared - manifod ] for a rational number @xmath40 and an integer @xmath236 , the pared orbifold @xmath440 is hyperbolic , i.e. , there is a geometrically finite hyperbolic @xmath61-orbifold @xmath257 such that for some @xmath476 and @xmath477 , @xmath440 is homeomorphic to @xmath478 where @xmath479 is the closed @xmath429-neighborhood of the convex core @xmath480 of @xmath257 , and @xmath481 and @xmath482 are @xmath477-thick part and @xmath477-thin part . here",
    "@xmath477 is chosen so that @xmath482 consists of only cuspidal part .    by the above proposition ,",
    "there is a faithful discrete representation @xmath483 which maps the conjugacy class represented by the loop @xmath446 to a parabolic transformation .",
    "recall that the heckoid group @xmath208 is a subgroup of @xmath150 of index @xmath0 or @xmath454 by proposition  [ prop : even_heckoid_group ] and definition  [ def : odd_heckoid_group ] and that it is generated by two elements in the conjugacy class of @xmath446 .",
    "hence , the restriction of @xmath484 to the subgroup @xmath64 gives the desired isomorphism from @xmath64 to a geometrically finite kleinian group generated by two parabolic transformations .    at the end of this section ,",
    "we prove the following proposition , which illustrates a significant difference between odd heckoid groups and even heckoid groups .",
    "[ prop - not - one - relator ] no odd heckoid group is a one - relator group .",
    "consider an odd heckoid orbifold @xmath53 . by proposition [ prop : odd - heckoid - orbifold ] ,",
    "the singular set of @xmath53 has two or four @xmath67-dimensional strata .",
    "note that the above proof of theorem  [ thm.kleinian_heckoid ] shows that @xmath53 is hyperbolic , and so the interior of @xmath53 is homeomorphic to a hyperbolic orbifold @xmath485 , where @xmath486 is a kleinian group isomorphic to @xmath65 .",
    "hence @xmath487 has two or four conjugacy classes of maximal finite cyclic subgroups , accordingly . on the other hand",
    ", any one - relator group has a unique maximal finite cyclic subgroup up to conjugacy ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  iv.5.2 ) ) .",
    "hence the odd heckoid group @xmath208 can not be a one - relator group .",
    "the second author would like to thank gerhard burde for drawing his attention to the work of riley  @xcite when he was visiting frankfurt in 1997 .",
    "the second author would also like to thank ian agol for sending him a copy of the slide of his talk  @xcite .",
    "both authors would like to thank yeonhee jang , makoto ozawa and toshio saito for helpful discussions and information concerning section  [ sec : kleinian - heckod - groups ] .",
    "they would also like to thank the referee for very careful reading and helpful comments .",
    "a.  selberg , _ on discontinuous groups in higher - dimensional symmetric spaces _ , 1960 ,",
    "contributions to function theory ( internat .",
    "function theory , bombay , 1960 ) , pp .",
    "147164 , tata institute of fundamental research , bombay ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> riley `` defined '' the heckoid groups for @xmath0-bridge links as kleinian groups , with nontrivial torsion , generated by two parabolic transformations , and he constructed an infinite family of epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto heckoid groups . in this paper , we make riley s definition explicit , and give a systematic construction of epimorphisms from @xmath0-bridge link groups onto heckoid groups , generalizing riley s construction .    _ in honour of j. hyam rubinstein and his contribution to mathematics _ </S>"
  ]
}
